steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cmssl","text":"In the remaining surface (now entirely blue), automatically detect and remove small and unconnected bone projections (\"outliers\" or \"islands\"), as these cannot typically be safely associated with the main entheseal changes observed (Filters --\u003e Cleaning and Repairing --\u003e Remove Isolated Pieces - wrt Diameter --\u003e Apply). In the pop-up window, set the diameter threshold to 2 mm and then click Apply (Fig. 26). ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5lb1j","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"er4qu","text":"Note that the percentage (%) automatically indicated next to that value (2 mm) tended to be around 5% for the example human specimens analyzed for developing this protocol and its associated validation paper.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"diutq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5gnr6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1j9mj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"33luq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2kj0h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8o26","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ec861","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b4hv3","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79bkr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"8DBA9A4A776011EFAE630A58A9FEAC02","height":371,"id":501060,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"aa3cp\",\"text\":\"Fig. 26: Snapshot of the remaining, blue-colored regions after automatically removing isolated pieces of 2 mm or less. Scale is not respected.\",\"type\":\"align-justify\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":9}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"26.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ri8ncgxdp.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rjkecgxdp.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rjkdcgxdp.webp","width":160}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":5,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":4,"offset":584,"style":"italic"}],"key":"euu7e","text":"Note: If setting the threshold to 2 mm removes all blue areas in the model (resulting in “0” areas) or eliminates structures that are critical for the analysis (i.e., visually identifiable entheseal changes), likely due to the small size or less smooth morphology of the enthesis, one option is to simply represent this particular enthesis in your dataset with a “0” area measurement. Alternatively, you may choose to repeat the entire delineation process with the threshold set to 1 mm instead of 2 mm (this parameter can also be directly edited and saved in a loaded Meshlab filter mlx script). If the threshold of 1 mm also removes critical features or the entire area, which can occur if the enthesis is very small or smooth (e.g., as in some entheses of small laboratory animals), you may also choose to skip this step (Step 21) altogether. Nevertheless, if you decide to skip this step or change the threshold for one specimen, then ensure that this decision is applied consistently across all specimens of the same enthesis in your sample.","type":"align-justify"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

Scale is not respected.\",\"type\":\"align-justify\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"27.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ri8rcgxdp.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rjkgcgxdp.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rjkfcgxdp.webp","width":171}}}}

steps.section: Part 4 – Delineation and measurement of projecting structures
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5uucl","text":"Measure the surface area of the final selected blue regions in square mm (provided the model is calibrated accordingly) by navigating to “Filters --\u003e Quality Measure and Computations --\u003e Compute Area/Perimeter of Selection”. The “Selection Surface Area” measurement will be displayed in the window at the bottom right corner of Meshlab (Fig. 28). The exact location of the measurement indication is also highlighted in the example delineation video provided in the \"Before starting\" section.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"kg4n","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ub04","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4utqt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"82co0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"B184F7DC776011EF82E30A58A9FEAC02","height":180,"id":501064,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"7ogol\",\"text\":\"Fig. 28: Display of the surface area measurement in the bottom right corner of the Meshlab window.\",\"type\":\"align-justify\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"28.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ri8vcgxdp.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rjkicgxdp.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rjkhcgxdp.webp","width":375}}}}

steps.section: Part 4 – Delineation and measurement of projecting structures
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"37miv","text":"Optionally, you may project the delineated entheseal changes onto the bone 3D model of the bone by importing the original 3D model file (e.g., the ply file of the first metacarpal) into Meshlab. To overlay this model, you may \"drag and drop\" the file into the same workspace where the processed model is displayed, by holding down the left mouse button during the action. This overlay process, as illustrated in Fig. 29 as well as the example delineation video provided in the \"Before starting\" section, allows you to visualize the selected regions on top of the bone model. It provides an opportunity for final verification to ensure that the workflow was executed correctly and to check for any potentially irrelevant areas still selected (e.g., areas outside the defined BSR or regions with clear taphonomic or pathological damage). If additional adjustments are needed, such as eliminating erroneously selected areas using Meshlab’s selection tools, document the decision and reasoning clearly in your study’s Methods section (optimally using illustrations). Eight additional examples of this process are illustrated below in Fig. 30, corresponding to the eight example cases of BSR selection discussed in Part 2 of this protocol (Case-Steps 2-9).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":147,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a7qgj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c27nu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9624t","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"eubv4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dl48v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2jtjg","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"52pv1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"C9FEC6B5776011EFAE630A58A9FEAC02","height":463,"id":501066,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"8meqb\",\"text\":\"Fig. 29: Optional overlay of the selected regions (3D entheseal changes) onto the original ply model of the first metacarpal for final verification. Scale is not respected.\",\"type\":\"align-justify\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":9},{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":91,\"length\":4}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"29.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ri8xcgxdp.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rjkkcgxdp.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rjkjcgxdp.webp","width":174}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"F2554739776011EFAE630A58A9FEAC02","height":705,"id":501068,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"em9n\",\"text\":\"Fig. 30: Additional examples of the optional overlay step, showing the selected and measured entheseal changes on the original bone 3D model for final verification. These examples correspond to the eight case studies and delineations discussed above in Part 2 (Case-Steps 2-9). In particular, the examples include the attachment sites of the following tissues: the second dorsal interosseus on the first metacarpal (A), extensor pollicis brevis on the first proximal hand phalanx (B), flexor pollicis longus on the first distal hand phalanx (C), third flexor digitorum superficialis on the third intermediate hand phalanx (D), opponens digiti minimi on the fifth metacarpal (E), deltoid on the humerus (F), costoclavicular ligament on the clavicle (G), and Achilles tendon on the calcaneus (H). Scale is not respected across panels.\",\"type\":\"align-justify\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8},{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":379,\"length\":11},{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":420,\"length\":24},{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":485,\"length\":22},{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":552,\"length\":30},{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":627,\"length\":22}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"30p.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ri8zcgxdp.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rjkncgxdp.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rjkmcgxdp.webp","width":550}}}}
